content.question: The position of a particle moving in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane is given by the parametric equations <math alttext="x of t equals, 5 times the natural log of, open parenthesis, t plus 5, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t equals, 5 times the sine of, open parenthesis, pi times t, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. At any point on the curve, the slope of the line tangent to the path of the particle is given by <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x equals, pi times the cosine of, open parenthesis, pi times t, close parenthesis, times, open parenthesis, t plus 5, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>. What is the value of <math alttext="the second derivative of y with respect to x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mo>ⅆ</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac></math> at <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.2: (BC ONLY) Second Derivatives of Parametric Equations

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
